text: The Roman numerals are derived from the Etruscan number symbols: 'ğŒ ', 'ğŒ¡', 'ğŒ¢', 'ğŒ£', and 'ğŒŸ' for 1, 5, 10, 50, and 100.
From the 14th century on, Roman numerals began to be replaced by Arabic numerals.
The number zero was missing from the classical Roman numeral system and was later represented by nulla / N.
The base 'Roman fraction' is S, indicating 1/2.
Apostrophus, Vinculum and other extension systems designed to indicate larger numbers were never standardised.
The largest number that can be represented in this notation is 3,999 (MMMCMXCIX)
Subtractive notation is when the first symbol is subtracted from the larger one. Example: IV is 5 - 1 = 4.
These are the only subtractive forms in standard use:4 (IV), 9 (IX), 40 (XL), 90 (XC), 400 (CD), 900 (CM).
Decimal system  was developed centuries before the Arabic numerals in the Indian subcontinent, using other symbols.
The Number Forms block of the Unicode character set has a number of Roman numeral symbols in the range of code points from U+2160 to U+2188.
